questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of a pruritic rash on both arms. He returned from a 2-week hiking trip in North Carolina 1 day ago. He has ulcerative colitis. He works as a landscape architect. His only medication is a mesalazine suppository twice daily. He has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 4 years and drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. He does not use illicit drugs. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 127/74 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ivermectin is used to treat scabies, pediculosis, and filariasis. Scabies presents with itching and erythematous papules in areas like the interdigital folds on the hands and feet, buttocks, and genital areas as opposed to plaques and vesicles localized to the arms. Additionally, no mite burrows are seen in the picture, making scabies unlikely in this man. Ivermectin will not help relieve his symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Counseling patients on alcohol intake is an important element in preventive medicine, especially in conditions like porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) that are exacerbated by alcohol. PCT commonly presents with blisters and erosions in sun-exposed areas – not the plaques and vesicles limited to the upper extremities seen above. Moreover, individuals with PCT have reddish-colored urine, which this man does not have. Alcohol cessation will not help his symptoms.

C) CORRECT:

Management of allergic contact dermatitis depends on symptom severity and affected areas. In mild to moderate cases, symptomatic therapy with cool compresses, wet dressings (for oozing, crusting lesions), and calamine lotion (to reduce pruritus) is indicated. Topical corticosteroids can be considered in patients with localized dermatitis. In patients with severe or refractory symptoms or a rash that covers a large or sensitive area of the body (e.g., face, genitals), systemic corticosteroids are indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone may be used in poison ivy dermatitis for patients with severe or refractory symptoms, or if the rash covers a large or sensitive area of the body (face or genitals), but this is not the case here. This patient has a short history of a limited rash, with no history of failed treatment attempts. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine used for symptomatic relief of allergies, urticaria, and rhinitis. The itching in poison ivy dermatitis, however, is due to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which has a different pathophysiology than the type I hypersensitivity reactions that antihistamines are best suited to treat. Sedating antihistamines may be used in those who have difficulty sleeping due to pruritus or in more severe cases.

F) INCORRECT:

Mesalazine is an aminosalicylate used to treat inflammatory bowel disease. While mesalazine can cause urticarial rashes or fixed drug eruption (FDE), which can manifest with erythematous plaques, the first onset of FDE occurs within 2 weeks of exposure to the drug. Additionally, it tends to recur with each exposure to the drug. This man has no history of rashes while using mesalazine. Discontinuing it is not likely to help his pruritus and may actually worsen his ulcerative colitis.
questions.hint: This man has developed multiple erythematous plaques and vesicles on his arms after a hiking trip, suggesting allergic contact dermatitis. It is most likely due to exposure to urushiol, the allergenic organic compound in poison ivy.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of a skin rash for one day. The patient reports intense itching. He was born at 39 weeks' gestation and has a history of atopic dermatitis. He attends junior high school and went on a camping trip with his school the day before yesterday. His older brother has celiac disease. Examination shows erythematous papules and vesicles that are arranged in a linear pattern on the right forearm. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A cytotoxic (i.e., type II hypersensitivity) reaction between IgG antibodies and hemidesmosomes in the epithelial basement membrane is the pathomechanism of bullous pemphigoid. Although bullous pemphigoid may present with localized pruritic skin lesions, the typical examination findings include large, tense, subepidermal blisters on palms, soles, lower legs, groin, and axillae. Furthermore, the disorder most commonly affects individuals 60 years and older, making it unlikely in this young patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Preformed IgE antibodies play a role in type I hypersensitivity reactions. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are classified as immediate immune responses and occur within minutes of antigen exposure. Symptoms of type I hypersensitivity reactions include pruritus, edema, urticaria, rhinitis, and bronchospasm. Atopic dermatitis is caused by this type of reaction and may manifest as a pruritic rash (i.e., eczema). Although the patient has a history of atopic dermatitis, the associated rash typically presents with lichenified lesions in flexural creases (antecubital and popliteal fossae), skin folds, and the extensor surface of hands, rather than a papulovesicular rash on one forearm.

C) INCORRECT:

In individuals with pemphigus vulgaris, IgG antibodies directed against desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1 account for the autoimmune reaction resulting in the formation of classic skin findings. In contrast to the patient's localized papulovesicular rash, pemphigus vulgaris manifests with painful, flaccid, intraepidermal blisters that rupture early and form erosions and crusts. Moreover, the lesions of pemphigus vulgaris typically present in individuals between 30–60 years of age initially on the oral mucosa, followed by body parts exposed to pressure (e.g., intertriginous areas).

D) INCORRECT:

Immune complex formation and deposition are the main mechanisms involved in type III hypersensitivity reactions. This type of reaction accounts for various immunological disorders including glomerulonephritides and vasculitides. Although symptoms may vary depending on the specific disorder, they tend to be systemic rather than localized, making this mechanism an unlikely cause of the patient's findings.

E) CORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which occurs in two distinct phases preceding the appearance of symptoms. During initial contact with the allergen, the antigen penetrates the skin and is taken up by Langerhans cells, which then migrate to lymph nodes, inducing the formation of sensitized T lymphocytes (i.e., sensitization). On repeated contact with the allergen, these presensitized T lymphocytes secrete lymphokines, which cause macrophage activation and an inflammatory reaction in the tissue (i.e., rash). The rash typically develops 12– 48 hours following contact and is therefore classified as a delayed immune response. Poison ivy, poison oak, and poison sumac are common causes.

Other typical causes include exposure to metals (e.g., nickel, cobalt, chromium), certain cosmetics (e.g., perfumes, soaps, sunscreens, hair dyes), latex, and topical medications (e.g., hydrocortisone, topical antibiotics, benzocaine).
Image Description:

An erythematous rash with numerous small vesicles in a linear pattern can be seen on the left forearm.

This rash is typical of mild allergic contact dermatitis caused by urushiol-containing plants (e.g., poison oak). In more severe cases, bullae and pronounced edema may be present.

F) INCORRECT:

IgA and complement C3 deposits in dermal papillae can be found in dermatitis herpetiformis, which may manifest with tense, grouped subepidermal blisters, and intense pruritus over the extremities, shoulders, abdomen, and gluteal region. The patient is at increased risk of developing this condition, given his family history of celiac disease, which is commonly associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. However, the distribution of the skin lesions would typically be symmetrical rather than unilateral. Furthermore, this patient does not have any symptoms of celiac disease (e.g., anemia due to iron deficiency, short stature), making dermatitis herpetiformis less likely.
questions.hint: This patient presents with pruritic, red skin lesions arranged in a linear pattern appearing 24 hours after a camping trip. These features suggest allergic contact dermatitis due to urushiol-containing plants, such as poison oak, poison ivy, or poison sumac.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician for evaluation of an intensely pruritic skin rash on his arms and legs for 12 hours. Two days ago, he returned from an annual camping trip with his son. The patient takes no medications. A photograph of the skin lesions on his left hand is shown. Activation of which of the following cell types is the most likely cause of this patient's skin findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient's rash suggests a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction (type IV hypersensitivity reaction) caused by exposure to allergens (e.g., poison ivy). Antigens penetrating the skin are phagocytosed by Langerhans cells, which subsequently migrate to the lymph nodes and there induce the formation of sensitized T lymphocytes. On a subsequent exposure, these presensitized T lymphocytes secrete lymphokines (e.g., interferon-γ) that induce macrophage-mediated tissue inflammation as seen in this patient. Examples of diagnostic tests that evaluate for a type IV hypersensitivity reaction include tuberculin skin test, Candida extract test, and patch test.

Other substances known to commonly cause delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions include metals (e.g., nickel), cosmetics, and topical medications.

B) INCORRECT:

Neutrophil recruitment and phagocytosis are promoted by immune complex deposition during type III hypersensitivity reactions. Many rheumatologic diseases involve type III hypersensitivity reactions, including rheumatoid arthritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, and Henoch-Schonlein purpura, all of which can manifest with skin lesions. However, these conditions would also present with symmetric, diffuse, and, possibly, systemic findings, unlike the localized pruritic skin rash seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

B cell-mediated hypersensitivity reactions can manifest with skin lesions either due to antibody formation against the tissue itself (type II hypersensitivity reaction such as bullous pemphigoid) or due to immune complex formation (type III hypersensitivity reaction such as Henoch-Schonlein purpura). However, this patient's localized pruritic rash in conjunction with the history of a camping trip 1–2 days ago suggest a different type of hypersensitivity reaction.

D) INCORRECT:

Mast cells provoke IgE-mediated immediate immune responses in type I hypersensitivity reactions. Symptoms of type I hypersensitivity include pruritus, edema, urticaria, rhinitis, and bronchospasm. Rashes due to type I hypersensitivity reaction are classically disseminated and diffuse, rather than localized to the area of likely exposure, as seen in this patient. Moreover, type I hypersensitivity reactions classically occur within minutes of antigen exposure. The history of a camping trip 1–2 days ago suggest a different cause of this patient's rash.

E) INCORRECT:

Eosinophil infiltration is a hallmark of type I hypersensitivity reactions. Mast cells degranulate in response to interaction with IgE, promoting the creation of platelet activating factor (PAF). PAF promotes platelet aggregation and the release of chemotactic factors to attract eosinophils. Rashes due to type I hypersensitivity reaction are classically disseminated and diffuse, rather than localized to the area of likely exposure, as seen in this patient. Moreover, type I hypersensitivity reactions classically occur within minutes of antigen exposure. The history of a camping trip 1–2 days ago suggest a different cause of this patient's rash.
questions.hint: The onset of pruritic vesicles arranged in a linear pattern shortly after outdoor activities suggests allergic contact dermatitis, e.g., due to contact with urushiol-containing plants such as poison oak, poison ivy, or poison sumac.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to the physician because of an itchy rash on his right arm for 1 day. The rash started as small papules, then progressed into blisters with oozing. He has had atopic dermatitis since the age of 6 years. His vital signs are within normal limits. A photograph of the patient's arm is shown. There is no lymphadenopathy. Avoidance of contact with which of the following would most likely have prevented this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cat dander is a potential trigger for an acute flare of atopic dermatitis (AD), which manifests with dry skin and intense pruritus. Patients with AD may develop excoriations due to itching that would appear as linear skin lesions. However, lesions in AD are not associated with papules and oozing vesicles. Moreover, AD is most likely to affect the flexural creases (e.g., antecubital fossa, popliteal fossa) instead of the forearm.
Image Description:

A solitary reddish-purple papule on an erythematous base is visible on the patient's right thenar eminence.

This appearance is typical of cat scratch disease, i.e., infection with Bartonella henselae.

B) INCORRECT:

The erythematous, pruritic, and papular rash on this patient's forearm could raise concern for papular urticaria. Papular urticaria is the result of a type I hypersensitivity reaction to insect bites or stings. However, it is not usually associated with linear streaks of small oozing vesicles. More commonly, bee stings cause a classical urticarial reaction (well-circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques), which is not seen here. Furthermore, bee stings are typically associated with pain and swelling at the affected site, which this patient does not report.
Image Description:

Multiple well-defined, erythematous, partially confluent lesions with raised serpiginous borders and central clearing are visible.

This is the characteristic appearance of urticaria, which typically has an acute onset, is highly pruritic, and transient.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's pruritic and erythematous papular rash with linear streaks of small oozing vesicles should raise suspicion for allergic contact dermatitis (ACD), a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. The characteristic skin lesions commonly appear 12–48 hours after exposure to the allergen in individuals that have previously been sensitized. Triggers of ACD include certain plants (i.e., poison oak, poison ivy, or poison sumac, which cause urushiol-induced dermatitis), nickel, rubber/latex, cosmetics, and certain topical medications. Management consists of avoidance of triggers, topical corticosteroids and wet dressings for mild to moderate cases, and systemic corticosteroids for severe cases (e.g., widespread rash, ACD involving the face).

D) INCORRECT:

The erythematous, pruritic papules and vesicles on this patient's forearm could be a result of a polymorphous light eruption (“sun allergy”). This photodermatosis is thought to be caused by a T cell-mediated type IV hypersensitivity response to high-intensity UV exposure after a period of little exposure (e.g., first prolonged sunlight exposure in spring or early summer). However, the rash associated with polymorphous light eruption is typically distributed in a bilateral, symmetric manner on several sun-exposed skin areas. This patient's rash is limited to his right arm, making this diagnosis unlikely.
Image Description:

Erythematous papules and lesions with irregular borders are visible on the cheeks and forehead.

E) INCORRECT:

The erythematous, pruritic papules and vesicles on this patient's forearm could be a form of dermatitis herpetiformis (DH), which can be caused by a T cell-mediated immunological response to gluten and is associated with celiac disease. However, DH is associated with grouped vesicles (herpetiform appearance) rather than the linear vesicles seen here. Moreover, DH is usually bilateral and symmetrical in distribution, as opposed to this patient's unilateral rash. Finally, this patient has no history of celiac disease and does not report associated symptoms such as gastrointestinal complaints or signs of malabsorption.
Image Description:

Grouped, erythematous, papulovesicular lesions that are partially excoriated (presumably due to pruritus) can be seen on the dorsal forearm.

These findings, especially in combination with pruritus, suggest dermatitis herpetiformis.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are likely the result of a T cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 22 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I want to have this mole on my left cheek removed because I don't like how it looks, and I'm afraid it will turn into skin cancer.”
History of Present Illness:

mole on left cheek since age 11 years

lesion has been growing in size; used to be flat and dark brown; now elevated and light brown
several moles on upper body
moles have increased in number since childhood; some have disappeared since adolescence

Past Medical History:
wisdom tooth extraction 6 months ago under local anesthesia; 24 hours later, local swelling, itching, and blistering at injection sites; anesthetic agent unknown

Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
local anesthetics
Family History:
noncontributory
Psychosocial History:

lives with parents
works as a market gardener
does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcoholic beverages, or use nonprescribed medications or other substances

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.9°C(98.4°F)
60/min
14/min
100/65 mm Hg
98% on RA
163 cm(5 ft 4 in)
57 kg(125 lb)
21.5 kg/m2




Appearance: no acute distress
Skin: warm, dry, and intact; 1 raised, papillomatous, uniformly light brown lesion with regular borders on left cheek, 5 mm in diameter; 7 similar lesions and 20 flat, well-demarcated light brown macules on upper trunk, shoulders, neck, and upper arms
HEENT: PERRLA
Neck: no cervical lymphadenopathy or masses
Pulmonary: clear lung fields bilaterally
Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops


Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of cetirizine followed by local anesthetic of choice
Mole removal with lidocaine as local anesthetic
Mole removal with procaine as local anesthetic
Referral to an allergist before mole removal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

General anesthesia has a higher risk of respiratory and cardiovascular complications than local anesthesia. Although general anesthesia is an option for urgent surgery, it is unwarranted for the elective removal of a mole, which can be performed under local anesthesia.

B) INCORRECT:

Antihistamines like cetirizine can reduce mild allergic symptoms (e.g., urticaria) in IgE-mediated type I hypersensitivity reactions by blocking or inhibiting histamine receptors. However, they are generally ineffective for treating allergic contact dermatitis, which is a T cell-mediated type IV hypersensitivity reaction.

C) INCORRECT:

Although lidocaine can be administered for elective mole removal, this patient has previously developed allergic contact dermatitis to an unspecified local anesthetic. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Although procaine can be administered for elective mole removal, this patient has previously developed allergic contact dermatitis to an unspecified local anesthetic. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

E) CORRECT:

Local swelling, itching, and blistering 12–48 hours after injection of a local anesthetic are consistent with allergic contact dermatitis to an unknown agent. Referral to an allergist to determine the causal local anesthetic is appropriate before proceeding with elective surgery.

Cross-reactivity between ester group anesthetics and amide group anesthetics is rare; therefore, if an allergy to one group is found, an anesthetic from the other group can be safely administered in future procedures.
questions.hint: Removal of a benign skin lesion, such as a common acquired melanocytic nevus (i.e., mole), is considered elective surgery.

questions.text:
A 31-year-old woman is evaluated for a skin rash. She initially noted the rash on her hands, and now it involves her neck and earlobes. She notes that she has stopped wearing earrings. She has a history of allergic rhinitis and had atopic dermatitis as a child.
On examination, the skin around her neck is erythematous and lichenified. Similar changes are noted on her earlobes. She also has a slight rash on her wrist, where she wears a watch.
Which one of the following tests is best for identifying the cause of this patient’s rash?

choices.text: Examine a skin scraping after applying potassium hydroxide (KOH) to it
Assess for presence of the Koebner phenomenon
Perform a patch test for nickel sensitivity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measuring the patient's eosinophil count would not be helpful in making a diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Although total serum immunoglobulin E levels are often elevated in patients with atopic dermatitis, these levels are neither diagnostic nor helpful in differentiating eczema from allergic contact dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Examining a skin scraping after applying potassium hydroxide (KOH) is useful for detecting fungal elements but is not used in evaluating causes of contact dermatitis. Although performing a KOH test on a scaly rash is not wrong, fungal infection is very unlikely in this clinical context.

D) INCORRECT:

The Koebner phenomenon, which refers to the development of skin disease at the site of skin trauma, is not a clinical feature observed in patients with contact dermatitis. It is often noted in diseases such as psoriasis, lichen planus, and sarcoidosis.

E) CORRECT:

The cause of an erythematous, lichenified skin rash can be difficult to determine because several different etiologic factors can lead to the same appearance. Although this patient had atopic dermatitis as a child, the location of the current skin lesions — in areas where she would wear jewelry — is more typical for allergic contact dermatitis, either in isolation or complicating her atopic dermatitis. Although many allergens could be responsible, the most likely culprit in this case is nickel, which is found in most jewelry and is the most frequent cause of jewelry contact sensitivity. Thus, a patch test for nickel is appropriate.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to identify the cause of a rash around a woman's neck, wrist, and earlobes is a patch test for nickel sensitivity.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman who cut her finger while cleaning a knife has been washing the wound daily with soap and water and applying an over-the-counter antibiotic ointment for the past 4 days. Today, she developed itchy red papules that are centered on and around the wound. There is no drainage from the wound, expanding erythema, fever, or pain.
What is the most appropriate initial step in the care of this patient?

choices.text: Discontinue the topical antibiotic and observe
Continue the topical antibiotic and add a topical glucocorticoid
Treat with a single dose of oral fluconazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wound infections are characterized by pain, heat, and purulent drainage. Without these signs and symptoms, oral antibiotics such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are not indicated. Should these signs be present, a wound culture followed by culture-directed antibiotics would be the best next step in management.

B) CORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that typically manifests within a few days of exposure, unless the patient is previously sensitized (in which case the reaction can occur within hours). Antibiotics, such as neomycin, that are contained in over-the-counter antibiotic ointments are among the most common cause of contact dermatitis. When the topical antibiotic is applied to open wounds, there can be rapid sensitization because antigen-presenting Langerhans’ cells are directly exposed to the chemical.

The most appropriate first step in care for this patient is to stop the topical antibiotic. If the reaction persists or the itch is severe, a mid- to high-potency topical glucocorticoid can be applied to diminish the inflammatory response.

Key learning point: Itchy red papules on a wound treated with an over-the-counter antibiotic ointment are often an indication of allergic contact dermatitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that typically manifests within a few days of exposure, unless the patient is previously sensitized (in which case the reaction can occur within hours). Antibiotics, such as neomycin, that are contained in over-the-counter antibiotic ointments are among the most common cause of contact dermatitis. The most appropriate first step in care for this patient is to stop the topical antibiotic. If the reaction persists or the itch is severe, a mid- to high-potency topical glucocorticoid can be applied to diminish the inflammatory response.

D) INCORRECT:

The antifungal fluconazole is not indicated for the treatment of contact dermatitis. Candida can infect fingernails, and dermatophyte infections can involve the nails and hands (onychomycosis and tinea manuum, respectively), but these fungal infections would not manifest in the manner described in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

Wound infections are characterized by pain, heat, and purulent drainage. Without these signs and symptoms, oral antibiotics such as cephalexin are not indicated. Should these signs be present, a wound culture followed by culture-directed antibiotics would be the best next step in management.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to the office because of a 2-day history of a pruritic rash on both arms. He returned from a 2-week hiking trip in North Carolina 1 day ago. He drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 65/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 127/74 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is shown. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

A) INCORRECT:

Ivermectin is used to treat scabies, pediculosis, and filariasis. Scabies presents with itching and erythematous papules in areas like the interdigital folds on the hands and feet, buttocks, and genital areas as opposed to plaques and vesicles localized to the arms. Additionally, no mite burrows are seen in the picture, making scabies unlikely in this man. Ivermectin will not help relieve his symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

PCT commonly presents with blisters and erosions in sun-exposed areas – not the plaques and vesicles limited to the upper extremities seen above. Sedating antihistamines may be used in those who have difficulty sleeping due to pruritus or in more severe cases.
questions.hint: This man has developed multiple erythematous plaques and vesicles on his arms after a hiking trip, suggesting allergic contact dermatitis. It is most likely due to exposure to urushiol, the allergenic organic compound in poison ivy.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old woman presents with a pruritic, erythematous rash on her neck to the Outpatient Clinic. She noticed the rash two days after starting a new scented moisturizer. She has no previous history of similar rashes. Examination shows tiny vesicles and well-demarcated patches in the area where the product was applied. She denies any respiratory distress or other systemic complaints.
Which of the following immunologic mechanisms most likely explains this patient’s skin findings?

choices.text: Immune complex deposition in superficial vessels

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immune complex deposition, a type III hypersensitivity reaction, leads to systemic symptoms like palpable purpura. This patient's localized vesicular rash, appearing at the moisturizer application site, indicates a localized reaction rather than a systemic immune complex-mediated process.

B) INCORRECT:

IgE-mediated mast cell degranulation is a type I hypersensitivity reaction, causing immediate symptoms like urticaria and angioedema. It occurs within minutes of allergen exposure and often involves systemic symptoms. The delayed rash onset and localized vesicular pattern in this patient suggest a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, not an IgE-mediated response.

C) INCORRECT:

Autoantibody-mediated damage, seen in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris, causes widespread blistering and mucosal involvement. The localized, pruritic vesicular rash following moisturizer use suggests a delayed T-cell–mediated hypersensitivity reaction, not an autoantibody-driven process.

D) CORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T lymphocytes. Small chemical agents in the scented moisturizer act as haptens, binding to skin proteins and forming new antigens. Langerhans cells capture these complexes and present them to T cells in lymph nodes, priming memory T cells. Upon re-exposure, these T cells release cytokines, recruiting immune cells and causing localized inflammation. This manifests as erythema, pruritus, and vesicle formation at the contact site. The delayed rash onset, 48–72 hours post-exposure, is characteristic of this cell-mediated response.

Key learning point: Allergic contact dermatitis is characterized by redness, itching, and burning at the site of contact with an allergen, often following the use of a new topical product.

questions.text: You are seeing a 14-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic by his parents for evaluation of a skin rash that began one day ago. He reports intense itching. He was born at term and has a history of atopic dermatitis. He attends junior high school and recently returned from a school camping trip two days ago. His older brother has celiac disease. He takes no medications and his immunizations are up-to-date. Vital signs are normal. On examination, there are erythematous papules and vesicles arranged in a linear pattern on his right forearm. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which one of the following is the most likely underlying cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In individuals with pemphigus vulgaris, IgG antibodies directed against desmoglein 3 and desmoglein 1 account for the autoimmune reaction resulting in the formation of classic skin findings. In contrast to the patient's localized papulovesicular rash, pemphigus vulgaris manifests with painful, flaccid, intraepidermal blisters that rupture early and form erosions and crusts. Moreover, the lesions of pemphigus vulgaris typically present in individuals between 30–60 years of age initially on the oral mucosa, followed by body parts exposed to pressure (e.g., intertriginous areas).

B) INCORRECT:

IgA and complement C3 deposits in dermal papillae can be found in dermatitis herpetiformis, which may manifest with tense, grouped subepidermal blisters, and intense pruritus over the extremities, shoulders, abdomen, and gluteal region. The patient is at increased risk of developing this condition, given his family history of celiac disease, which is commonly associated with dermatitis herpetiformis. However, the distribution of the skin lesions would typically be symmetrical rather than unilateral. Furthermore, this patient does not have any symptoms of celiac disease (e.g., anemia due to iron deficiency, short stature), making dermatitis herpetiformis less likely.

C) CORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which occurs in two distinct phases preceding the appearance of symptoms. During initial contact with the allergen, the antigen penetrates the skin and is taken up by Langerhans cells, which then migrate to lymph nodes, inducing the formation of sensitized T lymphocytes (i.e., sensitization). On repeated contact with the allergen, these presensitized T lymphocytes secrete lymphokines, which cause macrophage activation and an inflammatory reaction in the tissue (i.e., rash). The rash typically develops 12– 48 hours following contact and is therefore classified as a delayed immune response. Poison ivy, poison oak, and poison sumac are common causes.

Other typical causes include exposure to metals (e.g., nickel, cobalt, chromium), certain cosmetics (e.g., perfumes, soaps, sunscreens, hair dyes), latex, and topical medications (e.g., hydrocortisone, topical antibiotics, benzocaine).

Key learning point: Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction mediated by presensitized T lymphocytes, resulting in a delayed inflammatory skin response after allergen exposure.
Image Description:

An erythematous rash with numerous small vesicles in a linear pattern can be seen on the left forearm.

This rash is typical of mild allergic contact dermatitis caused by urushiol-containing plants (e.g., poison oak). In more severe cases, bullae and pronounced edema may be present.

D) INCORRECT:

Preformed IgE antibodies play a role in type I hypersensitivity reactions. Type I hypersensitivity reactions are classified as immediate immune responses and occur within minutes of antigen exposure. Symptoms of type I hypersensitivity reactions include pruritus, edema, urticaria, rhinitis, and bronchospasm. Atopic dermatitis is caused by this type of reaction and may manifest as a pruritic rash (i.e., eczema). Although the patient has a history of atopic dermatitis, the associated rash typically presents with lichenified lesions in flexural creases (antecubital and popliteal fossae), skin folds, and the extensor surface of hands, rather than a papulovesicular rash on one forearm.

E) INCORRECT:

Immune complex formation and deposition are the main mechanisms involved in type III hypersensitivity reactions. This type of reaction accounts for various immunological disorders including glomerulonephritides and vasculitides. Although symptoms may vary depending on the specific disorder, they tend to be systemic rather than localized, making this mechanism an unlikely cause of the patient's findings.
questions.hint: This patient presents with pruritic, red skin lesions arranged in a linear pattern appearing 24 hours after a camping trip. These features suggest allergic contact dermatitis due to urushiol-containing plants, such as poison oak, poison ivy, or poison sumac.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to your clinic for evaluation of a skin rash. She first noticed the rash on her hands, and it has since spread to her neck and earlobes. She mentions that she has stopped wearing earrings. Her medical history includes allergic rhinitis and childhood atopic dermatitis. On examination, there is erythema and lichenification of the skin around her neck and on her earlobes. There is also a mild rash on her wrist where she wears a watch. Which one of the following tests is best for identifying the cause of her rash?

choices.text: Examine a skin scraping after applying potassium hydroxide (KOH) to it.
Perform a patch test for nickel sensitivity.
Assess for presence of the Koebner phenomenon.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Measuring the patient's eosinophil count would not be helpful in making a diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis.

B) INCORRECT:

Examining a skin scraping after applying potassium hydroxide (KOH) is useful for detecting fungal elements but is not used in evaluating causes of contact dermatitis. Although performing a KOH test on a scaly rash is not wrong, fungal infection is very unlikely in this clinical context.

C) INCORRECT:

Although total serum immunoglobulin E levels are often elevated in patients with atopic dermatitis, these levels are neither diagnostic nor helpful in differentiating eczema from allergic contact dermatitis.

D) CORRECT:

The cause of an erythematous, lichenified skin rash can be difficult to determine because several different etiologic factors can lead to the same appearance. Although this patient had atopic dermatitis as a child, the location of the current skin lesions — in areas where she would wear jewelry — is more typical for allergic contact dermatitis, either in isolation or complicating her atopic dermatitis. Although many allergens could be responsible, the most likely culprit in this case is nickel, which is found in most jewelry and is the most frequent cause of jewelry contact sensitivity. Thus, a patch test for nickel is appropriate.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to identify the cause of a rash around a woman's neck, wrist, and earlobes is a patch test for nickel sensitivity.

E) INCORRECT:

The Koebner phenomenon, which refers to the development of skin disease at the site of skin trauma, is not a clinical feature observed in patients with contact dermatitis. It is often noted in diseases such as psoriasis, lichen planus, and sarcoidosis.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes to your clinic after cutting her finger while cleaning a knife. For the past 4 days, she has been washing the wound daily with soap and water and applying an over-the-counter antibiotic ointment. Today, she developed itchy red papules centered on and around the wound. There is no drainage, expanding erythema, fever, or pain. Which one of the following is the most appropriate initial step in her care?

choices.text: Continue the topical antibiotic and add a topical glucocorticoid.
Treat with a single dose of oral fluconazole.
Discontinue the topical antibiotic and observe.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that typically manifests within a few days of exposure, unless the patient is previously sensitized (in which case the reaction can occur within hours). Antibiotics, such as neomycin, that are contained in over-the-counter antibiotic ointments are among the most common cause of contact dermatitis. The most appropriate first step in care for this patient is to stop the topical antibiotic. If the reaction persists or the itch is severe, a mid- to high-potency topical glucocorticoid can be applied to diminish the inflammatory response.

B) INCORRECT:

The antifungal fluconazole is not indicated for the treatment of contact dermatitis. Candida can infect fingernails, and dermatophyte infections can involve the nails and hands (onychomycosis and tinea manuum, respectively), but these fungal infections would not manifest in the manner described in this case.

C) CORRECT:

Allergic contact dermatitis is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction that typically manifests within a few days of exposure, unless the patient is previously sensitized (in which case the reaction can occur within hours). Antibiotics, such as neomycin, that are contained in over-the-counter antibiotic ointments are among the most common cause of contact dermatitis. When the topical antibiotic is applied to open wounds, there can be rapid sensitization because antigen-presenting Langerhans’ cells are directly exposed to the chemical.

The most appropriate first step in care for this patient is to stop the topical antibiotic. If the reaction persists or the itch is severe, a mid- to high-potency topical glucocorticoid can be applied to diminish the inflammatory response.

Key learning point: Itchy red papules on a wound treated with an over-the-counter antibiotic ointment are often an indication of allergic contact dermatitis.

D) INCORRECT:

Wound infections are characterized by pain, heat, and purulent drainage. Without these signs and symptoms, oral antibiotics such as cephalexin are not indicated. Should these signs be present, a wound culture followed by culture-directed antibiotics would be the best next step in management.

E) INCORRECT:

Wound infections are characterized by pain, heat, and purulent drainage. Without these signs and symptoms, oral antibiotics such as trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole are not indicated. Should these signs be present, a wound culture followed by culture-directed antibiotics would be the best next step in management.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy comes to your clinic with a 1-day history of an itchy rash on his left forearm. The rash began as small papules and progressed to blisters with oozing. Vital signs are normal. A photograph of his forearm is provided. There is no lymphadenopathy. Avoidance of contact with which one of the following would most likely have prevented his symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The erythematous, pruritic papules and vesicles on this patient's forearm could be a result of a polymorphous light eruption (sun allergy). This photodermatosis is thought to be caused by a type IV hypersensitivity response to high-intensity UV exposure after a period of little exposure (e.g., first prolonged sunlight exposure in spring or early summer). However, the rash associated with polymorphous light eruption is typically distributed in a bilateral, symmetric manner on several sun-exposed skin areas and does not take on a linear pattern, as seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Cat dander is a potential trigger for an acute flare of atopic dermatitis (AD), which manifests with dry skin and intense pruritus. Patients with AD may develop papules, oozing vesicles, and excoriations due to itching that would appear as linear skin lesions. However, AD is most likely to affect the flexural creases (e.g., antecubital fossa, popliteal fossa) in adolescents, not the forearm.

C) CORRECT:

This patient's pruritic and erythematous papular rash with linear streaks of small oozing vesicles should raise suspicion for allergic contact dermatitis (ACD), a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. The characteristic skin lesions commonly appear 12–48 hours after exposure to the allergen in individuals who have previously been sensitized. Triggers of ACD include certain plants (i.e., poison oak, poison ivy, or poison sumac, which cause urushiol-induced dermatitis), nickel, rubber/latex, cosmetics, and certain topical medications. Management consists of avoidance of triggers, topical corticosteroids, and wet dressings for mild to moderate cases, and systemic corticosteroids for severe cases (e.g., widespread rash, ACD involving the face).

Key learning point: Urushiol‐induced allergic contact dermatitis typically manifests 12–48 hours after exposure as a linear papulovesicular rash.

D) INCORRECT:

Dermatitis herpetiformis (DH) is associated with grouped pruritic papules and vesicles on the extensor surfaces; it does not take on the linear pattern seen here. Moreover, DH is usually bilateral and symmetrical in distribution, as opposed to this patient's unilateral rash.

E) INCORRECT:

Papular urticaria is the result of a type I hypersensitivity reaction to insect bites or stings. However, it is not usually associated with linear streaks of small oozing vesicles. More commonly, bee stings cause a classical urticarial reaction (well-circumscribed, raised, erythematous plaques), which is not seen here. Furthermore, bee stings are typically associated with pain and swelling at the affected site.
questions.hint: This patient's symptoms are likely the result of a T cell-mediated hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-day history of a pruritic rash on both arms. He returned from a 2-week hiking trip in Ontario 1 day ago. He drinks one alcoholic beverage daily. His temperature is 36.8°C, pulse is 65/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 127/74 mm Hg. A photograph of the rash is provided. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Counseling patients on alcohol intake is an important element in preventive medicine, especially in conditions like porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) that are exacerbated by alcohol. PCT commonly presents with blisters and erosions in sun-exposed areas – not the plaques and vesicles limited to the upper extremities seen above. Moreover, individuals with PCT have reddish-colored urine, which this man does not have. Alcohol cessation will not help his symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

Cetirizine is a second-generation antihistamine used for symptomatic relief of allergies, urticaria, and rhinitis. The itching in poison ivy dermatitis, however, is due to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction, which has a different pathophysiology than the type I hypersensitivity reactions that antihistamines are best suited to treat. Sedating antihistamines may be used in those who have difficulty sleeping due to pruritus or in more severe cases.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral prednisone may be used in poison ivy dermatitis for patients with severe or refractory symptoms, or if the rash covers a large or sensitive area of the body (face or genitals), but this is not the case here. This patient has a short history of a limited rash, with no history of failed treatment attempts. Therefore, another step in management is more appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Ivermectin is used to treat scabies, pediculosis, and filariasis. Scabies presents with itching and erythematous papules in areas like the interdigital folds on the hands and feet, buttocks, and genital areas as opposed to plaques and vesicles localized to the arms. Additionally, no mite burrows are seen in the picture, making scabies unlikely in this man. Ivermectin will not help relieve his symptoms.

E) CORRECT:

Management of allergic contact dermatitis depends on symptom severity and affected areas. In mild to moderate cases, symptomatic therapy with cool compresses, wet dressings (for oozing, crusting lesions), and calamine lotion (to reduce pruritus) is indicated. Topical corticosteroids can be considered in patients with localized dermatitis. In patients with severe or refractory symptoms or a rash that covers a large or sensitive area of the body (e.g., face, genitals), systemic corticosteroids are indicated.

Key learning point: Mild to moderate allergic contact dermatitis is best managed with symptomatic therapy; systemic corticosteroids are reserved for severe or extensive cases.
questions.hint: This man has developed multiple erythematous plaques and vesicles on his arms after a hiking trip, suggesting allergic contact dermatitis. It is most likely due to exposure to urushiol, the allergenic organic compound in poison ivy.
